#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Teach Your Dog to Howl
#Text=Howling is a common method that dogs use to communicate with one another .
#Text=Dogs do not typically howl as a means of communicating or interacting with humans .
#Text=However , dogs are good learners and can be taught to howl on command .
#Text=If you ’d like to train your dog to howl on command , you ’ll need to find ways to encourage the behavior .
#Text=Be aware , though , that you may find it hard to stop your dog from howling once it 's begun !
#Text=Steps
#Text=Encouraging the Dog to Howl
#Text=Wait for the dog to howl on its own so you can reinforce the behavior .
#Text=It ’s tricky to make your dog howl before you ’ve trained it .
#Text=So , the first step is often just waiting for the dog to howl .
#Text=It may be inclined to howl if other nearby dogs start barking and howling , or if it hears a certain high-pitched sound like a fire-engine drive by .
#Text=Try taking your dog to a dog park if it ’s not inclined to howl .
#Text=Allowing your dog to interact with other dogs may prompt your dog to howl .
#Text=Find a sound that makes your dog howl if waiting does n’t work .
#Text=In many cases , a dog that is not inclined to howl will do so if it hears a certain sound or noise .
#Text=Try playing different genres of music around the house , and see if your dog howls to one .
#Text=Or , if you ( or a friend or family member ) play a musical instrument , play it around the house and see if it causes the dog to howl .
#Text=Play online videos of howling dogs to make your dog howl .
#Text=If music is n’t doing the trick , get on YouTube and search for “ dogs howling , ” then play some of the videos for your dog .
#Text=Your dog may be inclined to howl along when it feels like it ’s communicating with a real ( if pre-recorded ) dog .
#Text=Try a few different videos and see which elicits the best response from your dog .
#Text=Howl at your dog and see if it mimics you .
#Text=If music is n’t doing the trick , try mimicking a canine howl when you and your dog are in the same room .
#Text=A dog is often inclined to mimic its owner ’s behaviors — or might just get excited by your loud howling — and should be inclined to howl along with you .
#Text=If your dog is n’t inclined to howl , do n’t harass the animal .
#Text=Do n’t try to force the dog to howl if it does n’t want to .
#Text=Teaching the Dog to Howl on Command
#Text=Say “ howl ” when the dog howls .
#Text=Once you ’ve figured out a way to make your dog howl , you need to start using the command that you ’d like to induce the dog to howl .
#Text=Whenever you play a sound that makes your dog howl , approach the howling dog and say , “ howl ! ”
#Text=If the dog ’s howl is very loud , raise your voice so the dog can hear you over its own howl .
#Text=Give your dog time to link the “ howl ” command and the howling behavior .
#Text=It may take a few weeks for the dog to be fully trained to howl .
#Text=If you prefer , you could say “ sing ” instead .
#Text=Just be sure that you ’re consistent with the command you give the dog .
#Text=Reward the dog with a treat each time you say “ howl . ”
#Text=The two can be done simultaneously .
#Text=Once the dog begins to howl , say “ howl ” ( or “ sing ” ) in a firm tone .
#Text=Then give the dog a treat .
#Text=This will reinforce the howling behavior , and teach the dog to associate the behavior with your command .
#Text=Continue to reinforce the howling behavior over a period of days ( or weeks ) .
#Text=During this stage of the training , you may still need to occasionally stimulate the dog to howl by using music , a YouTube video , or your own voice .
#Text=Be specific with the behaviors that you reinforce .
#Text=A howl is different than a bark or a yip , and so the dog should n’t be given a treat for barking when you want it to howl .
#Text=Provide a nonverbal cue if you want your dog to respond to a signal .
#Text=Train the dog to respond to a different cue instead .
#Text=If you ’d rather not give the “ howl ” command , try using another cue .
#Text=Some dog owners may prefer to train their dog to howl when given a nonverbal cue .
#Text=The process is identical to training the dog to howl to the “ howl ” command , but you ’ll use the nonverbal cue in conjunction with the dog treat .
#Text=For example , you could train the dog to howl to the sound of a certain piano note or to howl every time you clap your hands or snap your fingers .
#Text=Wean the dog off of the treats .
#Text=Once your dog has come to understand the connection between hearing the “ howl ” command and howling , you can begin to cut back on the number of treats it receives .
#Text=For example , still give the “ howl ” command but only give a treat half the time .
#Text=A few days later , cut back to only giving a treat a quarter of the time .
#Text=Then , cut out the treats altogether .
#Text=If you like the idea of giving your dog a treat each time it howls on command , you can skip this step .
#Text=Use the “ quiet ” command and reward your dog when it stops howling .
#Text=This can help you control the amount of noise they make later on .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Be aware that not all breeds of dogs howl .
#Text=If you ’ve never heard your dog howl — even when other neighborhood dogs are howling , or when a firetruck drives by — your dog may not be a howling breed .
#Text=Breeds that frequently howl include Beagles , Dachshunds , Coonhounds , Foxhounds , Hounds , and Huskies .
#Text=If you ’d like confirmation about whether or not your dog ’s breed can howl , ask your veterinarian .
